reviewText:
No question: the movie is good and actors too, but the DVD-R not.
Its NOT restored and doesn't contains any subtitles (english SDH, which I need because foreign speaking and hard hearing).

i have been wanting to see this film again for many years after seeing a beautiful cinema presentation years ago.this print however has not been restored,and all that magnificent scenery,and splendid costuming has gone to waste.the film itself is a rather dull talkative affair which fails to maintain ones interest,despite a great cast of 50's stars ;cornel wilde,anne francis,michael wilding,and george sanders.theres not much swashbuckling here, not much action,in fact not much of anything.very average script,and pedestrian direction... If you are expecting an exiting colourful action packed adventure you'll be dissapointed.

This is a well told, equally well photographed story with a superb cast set during Benedict Arnold's defection to the British during the American Revolution. It was a find. I hope there are more movies like this waiting to be re-discovered.

Carl E. Ramsey

Set during the Revolutionary War, Cornel Wilde plays a Major in the Continental army trying to uncover a British plot to get information from an American spy. The Scarlet coat is how that intrigue develops and the circumstances leading to Benedict Arnold's treason. A great movie and one of my favorites over the years. Seen rarely but now an addition to my collection, so I can see it when I want.
love this type of movie
Excellent.  I wish it had been a bit more true to fact, however.

I've always enjoyed movies starring Cornel Wilde and I find this color version no exception.  The background of this story is based on historical events that took place during the War for American Independence. He portrays an American spy involved in discovering the traitorous actions of General Benedict Arnold and his attempt to turnover West Point to the British.  The main British spy (Major Andre, Michael Wilder) was also a historical character. George Sanders is a solid actor and also contributes to an overall good movie.

I will first admit that I am not sure if this is historically accurate but it does seem so. My one complaint about it is that it is advertised as the story of Benedict Arnold and also to be honest, except for him being a spy for the British I didn't know much about it or him. This wasn't so much about him but instead of the British Major Andre and American infiltrator Major Bolton played by Cornel Wilde. Anne Francis has a small let's get a woman in here part. George sanders if an evil British man. I did instead enjoy the new story of the Majors but still was left hanging (get it) by the lack of Benny Arnold story. A very good movie, well acted and good story telling. I do recommend it.
Outstanding movie.  Was delivered on time and have enjoyed over and over.

I loved this story and have watched it at least twice more since I saw it the first time.  It is an exciting story of the American Revolution.  I doubt if it is a true story, but it is still fun to watch.

This video is a plausible, fictionalized, account of Benedict Arnold and Major Andre.  It is spectacular because of the costuming.  The different types of uniforms, especially the dragoons, make this an interesting spectacle for historians, even though the American agent story is purely notional.  The secret message systems are accurate for the period.

"The Scarlett Coat" is a 1955 color historical drama about events surrounding the treason of Benedict Arnold.

Cornel Wilde (1912-89) plays a double agent who is working to uncover the identity of the traitor within the American ranks. Wilde appeared in more than 50 films and was nominated for his work in "A Song to Remember" (1945). He's probably best known for his work as the Great Sebastian in "The Greatest Show on Earth" (1952) but I think his best work was in "The Naked Prey" (1966), a film he also directed and produced. His acting in this film is pretty wooden.

Michael Wilding (1912-79) plays Major John Andre, and though Wilding is second billed, the story really focuses on him. Wilding is probably better known for having married Elizabeth Taylor, rather than the 50+ films he appeared in.

Suave George Sanders (1906-72) appeared in hundreds of films, often as a villain. He's best remembered as film critic Addison DeWitt in "All About Eve" (1950) for which he won the Oscar as Best Supporting Actor. Here he plays a Tory who suspects Wilde of being a double agent.

John McIntire (1907-91) plays General Howe. McIntire had the unique distinction of filling in for an actor who died in the middle of a series (Ward Bond in "Wagon Train"). In a career from 1947 to 1989 he made nearly 100 films and appeared in many TV shows and movies. Although he usually appeared in westerns, I remember him best for his TV series "Naked City" (1958). He was usually a good guy, but could also play the bad guy (e.g., "Winchester 73", "The Far Country").

Beautiful Anne Francis (1930-2011) was the award winning star of "Honey West" on TV (1965-6). She graced us with her beauty in films like "Blackboard Jungle" (1955), "Forbidden Planet" (1956), and "Funny Girl" (1968). She plays Wilde's love interest.

John Sturges (1910-1992) was nominated for an Oscar and a Palme d'Or for "Bad Day at Black Rock" (1955) and for a DGA for "Gunfight at the OK Corral" (1957), but my favorite Sturges films are "The Magnificent Seven" (1960) and "The Great escape" (1963). This film has none of the action we associate with Sturges.

In 1955  "Lady and the Tramp", "Mister  Roberts", Guys and Dolls", "Rebel Without a Cause" and "Picnic" were the top 5. The Oscars went to "Marty" (Picture, Director, Actor), "Mister Roberts" (Supporting Actor), "East of Eden" (Supporting Actress), and "The Rose Tatoo" (Actress). Other notable films released that year were "The 7 Year Itch", "Blackboard Jungle", "Lady and the Tramp", "Oklahoma", "To Catch a Thief" and "The Virgin Queen".

My favorite American Revolution film is John Ford's "Drums Along the Mohawk" (1939). "The Crossing" (2000) is a distant second. Most of the rest, like "The Devil's Disciple" (1959), "The Howards of Virginia" (1940), and "John Paul Jones" (1959) are OK."The Patriot" (2000) and "Revolution" (1985) are just plain silly. The TV mini-series "The Adams Chronicles" (1976). "The Revolution" (2006), and "John Adams" (2008) are probably the best sources about the period.

Bottom line - this is a pretty ordinary film.

this story is not all true....my  great ancestor grandfather david williams  was the  real hero  and  there are monuments in tarrytown  dedicated to him.....also george  washington  gave  him a  log  cabin  land  and  money  for the  rest of his  life....thank you  for  listening
i simply love this movie for the actors always play their part so well. and even more so because it,s in color . Thank you for bringing out this movie on dvd.

The movie itself is good, but the DVD leaves a lot to be desired.  There are no subtitles or closed- captioning.  I watched the movie today on TCM and saw a much better picture, as well as subtitles.  If you simply want to watch the movie and don't mind the quality, this will probably suffice.

A great story that is beautifully filmed and acted. I know it takes many historical liberties but nonetheless I thoroughly enjoyed it. I don't normally get very emotional over movies but the ending of this always brings me to tears big time!
Just watched Turn - so interested in the period. Movie is outdated, but interesting to compare.

I became interested in the history of Major Andre after watching the TV Series "Turn: Washington's Spies" which was excellent. This movie is equally excellent in telling the story of Major Andre and Tallmadge. The following Kindle books provided an authentic background for the characters involved in this story: A Journal of the Operations of the Queen's Rangers from the End of the Year 1777, to the Conclusion of the Late American War (1789) Peggy Shippen, The Traitorous Belle of the American Revolution: Brief Historical Accounts of Mrs. Benedict Arnold Major André's Journal The Life and Career of Major John Andr: Adjutant-general of the British Army in America (1861) The Secret Spy Service of the American Revolution (1882) Vindication of the Captors of Major Andr (1865) The Fate of Major Andr: A Letter from Alexander Hamilton to John Laurens Memoir of Col. Benjamin Tallmadge The Life of George Washington (1855) Although there are differences between the actual history of this story and the movie version, the movie was very entertaining and is highly recommended.

I give this three stars because this movie was made in Cinema Scope  (2.55:1 ) when it first came out and it is being presented here
in a different ratio of (1.77:1).  What a shame.
Beautiful costumes and sets. Michael Wilding is charismatic as Andre and gorgeous in his scarlet coat.
The DVD arrived in fine condition n plays fine.
Good old swashbuckler. Not outstanding, but for old costume flicks, check it out.
Hollywood version of critical events during the revolutionary war...strong cast saves the day...entertaining re-telling of the Benedict Arnold saga...
Hollywood version of Arnold/Andre story, not bad at all...At least it strives to be fairly accurate....
